properties.Description: This private yacht was swamped in heavy seas near Chapel Rock.

AKA: the Murray Bay wreck, the Bermuda sank nearby, was raised and moved to Grand Island and allowed to resink pending salvage that never came about.  She is popular with sport divers because of her depth and condition. The wreck is upright in shallow water and the top deck is reached at just 12 feet. Three large hatches open to the cargo hold and two companionways. A large cabin trunk, where the cabin blew off while sinking, is near the stern. Schools of Rock Bass and other colorful game fish are common.
The Chenango was in tow of the steamer Jay C. Morse, carrying a cargo of pig iron when it broke loose in a squall, and grounded near Wood Island.

One of three schooner-barges that left Pequaming in tow of the steamer P.H. Birckhead, all loaded with lumber for lower-lakes ports. They spent one day at shelter off Marquette before proceeding to Whitefish Point. As they tow rounded the point, towlines snapped, setting the barges loose.  One schooner-barge went to anchor, with the crew being rescued by lifesavers, one schooner made sail and reached shelter. The Birckhead reached the Elma and passed another tow-line and headed for shelter near Grand Island, where the towline broke again and the Elma damaged her rudder, leaving her unable to make sail. The Elma finally went on the rocks off Miners Castle.  One crewman was lost getting a line ashore, but eventually the remaining crew were able to scale the cliff and reach safety.

This schooner was carrying a cargo of iron ore when she grounded off Grand Island's Sand Point.  She was salvaged the next year, with her gear and part of her cargo being recovered, but the remainder lies scattered in the shallows.

Upbound with coal when a strong north wind blew her onto the shoals off Au Sable Point.  Salvagers recovered some of her cargo, but rising winds eventually damaged the vessel enough that it was abandoned. She lies scattered about on a sandstone ledge, with her boilers, anchors, and other gear moved about by ice and wave action.

The George was bound for Marquette with 1,330 tons of coal when it ran into a snowstorm in October 1893. The captain attemped to shelter behind Grand Island but as winds increased, the George was blown ashore off Pictured Rocks, 2 miles east of Miners Castle.  The crew was able to use the yawl to reach safety.  The vessel broke up near the shore, with the centerboard box, keelsons, and large sections of the hull remaining, from the edge of the rocks out to the mouth of the cove.

A severe storm forced the Hettler to seek refuge in Munising Harbor. She  slammed into a rock reef while trying to find the passage. The wreck now rests broken up in 30 to 40 feet of water.  On the inner edge of the shoal where the Hettler struck, her boiler can be found in about 25 feet of water along with parts of the hull and a large debris field with a variety of mechanical parts, tanks, piping and even a bath tub.

The Kiowa was a 251 ft long steel bulk freight steamship that was driven ashore in a gale on November 30, 1929. The remains lie in 40 feet of water. Huge sections of her hull are visible from the surface on clear days. The stern lies on her port side exposing the steamers' steering quadrant and emergency steering gear. A short distance forward, an enclosed ladder way leads down toward the propeller shaft tunnel. At the end of the tunnel, the propeller shaft and massive thrust bearing can be seen.
This vessel stranded inside Grand Marais harbor with a cargo of general freight and passengers.

The Manhattan took refuge in Oct 1903 from a Lake Superior storm. When she departed the next day, October 26, 1903, her steering failed causing her to strike a reef, and a fire broke out. She burned to the waterline and was later partially salvaged. What remains today lies in 20 to 40 feet of water. Divers can see the steamer's hull framing as well as her enormous rudder with its depth markings still visible.

The schooner was thrown ashore on the mainland west of Grand Island by roaring winds.  She was hard aground, but it was hoped she could be raised in the spring.  However, winter weather broke the vessel apart, leaving salvors little to recover.

The Mary Jarecki was heading for the Soo from Marquette when she ran up on Au Sable Point at full speed in foggy conditions.  Salvage was attempted, even using pontoons, but she was holed too badly and finally went to pieces in a September storm.

The Mary M Scott was grounded on Sand Point while trying to take shelter in a storm.  Her remains are exposed and recovered periodically in the shifting sands about 3/8 mile north of the point proper.

Under command of her namesake, Capt Michael Groh, she was downbound with lumber from Marquette when she broke a steam line to her engine, leaving her to drift until she grounded near where the Elma was lost.  Nearly alf of her 325,000 bd-ft cargo from the Dead River Mill was salvaged but the remainder lies scattered on the bottom along with portions of her hull.

This schooner ran aground in heavy weather while carrying a cargo of pig iron from Marquette.  Her remains can be seen in the shallows as you walk the shoreline towards Au Sable Point, along with those of Mary Jarecki and Union.
This schooner apparently stranded inside east breakwall of Grand Marais' harbor with a cargo of lumber.

The Sitka ran south of her normal course and onto a rock ledge at full speed, leaving her well out at the forward end.  The local lifesavers stood by, and finally took the crew off when the seas built up and broke her apart.  Wreck portions remain on the reef and nearer to shore.

The Smith Moore was damaged in a collision with the James Pickands on July 13, 1889 on Lake Superior and sank near Grand Island while being towed towards shelter at Munising.  She rests now in 105 feet of water with the deck at 80 ft.  Much machinery is visible, and open deck hatches afford access to the interior.

The Selvick is an intentionally sunk shipwreck placed for sport diving in 1996. She is a 70 foot long tug sunk in 60 feet of water. She lies leaning on her port side at about a 40 degree angle, pointing north. The Selvick was originally christened the Lorain when she was built at Cleveland in 1915.  She was later renamed the Cabot and was used in the construction of the Mackinac Bridge. All areas of the wreck are accessible to divers. The pilothouse, galley, mess room, engine room and crew quarters can all be visited.

She came to a tragic end when she lost her rudder and cargo shifted in heavy seas, leaving her helpless.  She drifted onto the rocks near Spray Falls, with the loss of 42 persons.  The ships engine and safe were later salvaged.  Her 3 boilers remain, along with portions of the hull, only about 100 ft offshore, 300 ft west of Spray Falls, near large rocks.  Other machinery lies scattered about the area.
This small steamer was forced into the shallows by an early-season gale, where she broke apart.

Driven ashore after she broke her tow cable to the tug Samson.  The hull broke in two places on either side of the mainmast, and the crew endured a rough night onboard before being rescued the next day.  Portions of the hull lie near shore, while some frames and part of the coal cargo have been moved farther out.

Driven ashore after she broke her tow cable to the tug Samson.  The hull broke in two places on either side of the mainmast, and the crew endured a rough night onboard before being rescued the next day.  Portions of the hull lie near shore, while some frames and part of the coal cargo have been moved farther out.

Launched as the Roswell P. Flower, she was briefly the largest wooden vessel on the Great Lakes. In 1915 she was renamed the Agnes W. after the daughter of her new owner. On July 2, 1918 she was carrying a cargo of grain when she was caught in a severe summer storm. She stranded near Traverse Point and was pounded to pieces in the storm. Her remains are spread out in about 15 feet of water.  Her machinery was salvaged, leaving only the lower hull portions, surrounded by an assortment of small artifacts.

According to Drummond Island website and Fish Tugs of the Great Lakes website: In 1931 this vessel was owned by Albert McLeod of Detour, MI.  Sometimes confused with another Alice C. (No. 107684 built in Manitowac in 1901 and owned by John Girvin of Manistuque MI. )

The remains of this canal schooner come to within a few feet of the surface in this protected cove. A jug often marks one end of the wreck to guide boaters past.  The hull is largely intact, while the decking has slid off to the north.  The vessel lies east-west, with damage to both ends.

The small steamer E. J. LaWay was built at Cheboygan, Michigan in 1914. The �E.J.� measured 73 feet long and 20 feet in beam. On April 19, 1929, she was transporting a load of coal when she was cut by ice. Her captain tried to beach her on a nearby island but failed to make it and she settled into about 50 feet of water. Today, she sits on the bottom listing slightly to port with
the stern being higher than the bow. The forward section of the vessel has collapsed and split open, but from the cargo hatch rearward the hull is largely intact. The pilot house and rear upper decks and cabins have fallen forward and to port. Most of the upper decks, cabins and their contents lie in a large debris feld on the bottom off the port side of the hull. A large steam windlass is situated on the main deck. The boiler and steam engine can be found intact with gauges and a steam condenser. This is a very impressive shipwreck for divers of all experience levels.

The General was rammed and sunk in the St. Mary's River in 1910, spending 7 years submerged before being raised for further use by the Durocher Company of Detour.  She later burned off Frying Pan Island and lies today in water about 15 to 25 feet deep. The engine, boiler and major machinery were salvaged. What remains are the hull and some portions of the cabins. Near the stern is a very large steering quadrant that was connected to the vessel’s steering wheel. This site is usually sheltered from inclement weather.

This schooner-barge was led into the shallows by her shallower-draft towing steamer H.B.Tuttle.  The Tuttle bounced over the shoal, the Ely was hung up and turned broadside to the pounding seas.  Her coal cargo was salvaged, tearing much of the vessel apart in the process.
The remains of this small freighter can be seen from the surface, but much of the cargo of farm machinery was salvaged years later.

This package steamer caught fire,exploded, and burned to the waterline leaving her badly broken up. The wreck is very accessible in just 5 to 15 feet of water off the westerly shore of Little Trout Island. Much of her remains can be easily examined including a large 8 foot diameter bronze propeller.

On October 14, 1893, she was carrying a load of coal in tow of the steamer F. E. Spinner. The boats encountered a violent storm and the steamer cut her loose. The captain of the Merrill tried to seek safety but ran up on Holdridge Shoal near the De Tour Passage entry, stranding the crew for 24 hrs before rescue. The anchor is found in 30 ft of water, following the chain will take divers to the keelsons at 65 ft.  Divers can see many small artifacts like tools, ship's hardware and personal effects in addition to the capstan and windlass.
100 yards east of the Sainte Marie, the John Cullen is an abandoned dredge.  Large timbers and entanglement hazards exist.

A simple grounding at the west end of Crab Island Shoal quickly led to the loss of this vessel.  Deck & rigging were salvaged but some of her coal cargo is strewn about on the bottom, with a few small artifacts mixed in.

Having just been sold to a Canadian firm, she burned and sank with a full cargo of cement and hay while upbound with a pair of schooner-barges for Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.  Islanders filled the hull with limestone blocks and used it as a harbor breakwall.  It is a good snorkeling site.

The Sainte Marie was a railroad car ferry that once ran between Mackinaw City and St. Ignace. It was purchased for use as a barge for hauling materials between Detour and Drummond Island. After several years of service she was abandoned in 1928.  With poor visibility, a slight current, and protruding spikes and cables, this site is an entanglement hazard to divers.
Built as a yacht, she was later converted to a fish tug.  Last owned by the Kreetan Company, a lumbering firm based in Johnswood, Drummond Is.
An aged wooden scow-steamer, she burned to a total loss. Remains are found along and under the southern breakwall entrance to Detour Harbor.
An aged schooner barge used in the lumber trade, she was abandoned to rot in Scammon Cove near the Silver Spray.

A small steamer converted to a lighthouse tender, abandoned at Watson's dock.  Wreck was broken when raised by a crane in the 1970's, and the remains were scattered.  The remaining debris and associated dock ruins make for an interesting dive.
Ended career as a floating "speak-easy", it sank largely intact.  No deck cabins, but interior is still wide open, as it was used for dancing & parties.

properties.VesselType: Fish Tug - originally steam, 100-120hp Kahlenberg semi-diesel 1928
properties.Builder: Ulyses McCann for Charles Hendrickson, Jr. of Charlevoix MI
properties.Description: Partially intact wood fish tug is in 20 to 40 feet of water. Reportedly became tangled in a net from a fisheries research vessel owned by the Michigan Department of Natural Resources, and was dragged from 80 feet of water to her present location. This is a site for many open water training dives due to its proximity to shore and the ease of entry.  Last owner Frank Sears of Traverse City 1942, used as tow tug.

Sunk in 1903 while tied up at the Elk Rapids Cement Company dock, the remains of this 100' scow can be found just south of the Elk Rapids harbor in 12 feet of water. This is an ideal site for snorkelers.
The remains of a (presumed) schooner sunk around 1894. Not much is known.  Possibly the Ada, the Brick, Two Fannies, or Morning Star.

Sailing from Elk Rapids to Sandusky with 585 tons of pig iron, she began leaking badly and turned back the following day. Realizing that he could not make port, Capt. Frank Conlin attempted to beach the vessel on Old Mission Point, but sank before reaching land. Much of the cargo was salvaged by the firm of Dexter & Noble, of Elk Rapids.

properties.Location: Elk River dock, Grand Traverse Bay
properties.Description: Early 1900's barge, shallow enough for snorkeling, 50 yds out from US31 boat launch.
The remains of a fruit or potato barge in 3 ft of water.  Just off the boat launch.
A small wooden tug 100 yds. off the Northport public beach, with two intact boilers - one off the wreck.

Became lost in a snow storm in November 1886 and grounded south of Old Mission Point.  Wreck was abandoned after the cargo of pig iron and lumber was salvaged.  The remains are divided into a shallow debris field just offshore in only about 8 feet of water and a deeper portion of the hull in 120 feet.

Became lost in a snow storm in November 1886 and grounded south of Old Mission Point.  Wreck was abandoned after the cargo of pig iron and lumber was salvaged.  The remains are divided into a shallow debris field just offshore in only about 8 feet of water and a deeper portion of the hull in 120 feet.
Also known as the Double Ender, this is the intact remains of a neglected sloop that sank in the 1970's in southern West Bay.
A 55� tug built in1926 that sank in the 1970�s. Her wreck is semi-intact and is a popular dive site in about 44 feet of water near Power Island.
Discovered by divers and quickly stripped in the 1970's.  Cabins intact, engine still in place.

Ran ashore at Mott Island in a blinding snowstorm, bow broke off and sank in deep water.  14 passengers and crew were rescued a day later.  Some salvage work done in 1886.  Bow location unknown, possibly included in salvage.

This package freighter spent her life servicing the Isle Royale community and Minnesota north shore by providing transportation, mail and provisions. On her first run of the 1928 season, an inexperienced first mate ran her onto a rocky reef off Washington Harbor at the southwest end of Isle Royale. In an attempt to save her, she was run hard aground just offshore, but the steeply sloped bottom left the stern at 80 ft with the bow above water. Subsequent efforts to salvage the wreck failed for technical or financial reasons.  Ice damage is evident to a depth of 30 feet but much of the America’s deck gear, including her windlass remains. The engine room is remarkably intact with its piping, engine and other equipment. The boilers did not explode in the sinking and are intact. Crew quarters and numerous cabins can be reached and examined.

The Congdon was off course when she ran up on Canoe Rocks at the north end of the Isle Royale. The freighter broke apart as the storm continued. The bow portion, including the pilothouse, broke off cleanly and now sits upright in 70 to 110 feet of water. The remainder of the ship settled into much deeper water on the opposite side of the reef.

Lost near the Rock of Ages Lighthouse, her remains lie in 20 - 80 feet of water. The wreckage is broken and scattered with portions of her wooden hull, side-wheel and boiler in the debris field, mixed with wreckage of the Henry Chisholm.

This steel freighter was lost in June 1947 when she ran aground on a rocky reef off Isle Royale.  She sank quickly with the bow resting in 25 to 60 feet of water and the stern in deeper water. The ice has damaged the shallow portions of the wreck and the pilothouse is gone. However, anchors and much of her deck equipment remain to be explored in her forward section. Her stern includes her rudder and propeller, engine room and numerous cabins.

Lost in a low fog , she ran aground at Rock of Ages Lighthouse in 1933. She rests in water 40 to 100 feet deep with her wreckage scattered. Her machinery, equipment, propeller, and steel plates are visible on the bottom.

Built as the William H. Gratwick in 1893 and later sold to a Canadian. This shallow wreck lies in 15 to 60 feet of water. Lost in 1924 by grounding on rocky shoals. Because of its shallow depth, the wreck’s remains lie scattered about the reef, including the propeller, engine and boilers.
The engine and rudder of the Chisholm slid down the reef into deeper water.

The Chisholm left Duluth towing the 220-ft. schooner John Martin on a run down the lakes. The weather worsened off the Keewenaw and the Martin was set loose while Chisholm found shelter.  After the blow, while searching for her lost tow, the Chisholm ran onto Rock of Ages Reef and punctured her hull.  The ship was pounded by weather before salvage could be effected.  The wreckage of her hull is mingled with that of the Cumberland.

On her last run of the 1906 season, she ran at full speed in poor visibility onto the Palisades at the north end of Isle Royale.  The engineer ignored orders to reverse the engine after she hit, holding her on shore and preventing her from sinking in deeper water.  A crewman climbed ashore with a line the next morning, and everyone was able to make it to safety.
Towing barge Grampian, she ran onto a bar and was struck from behind by the tow, where she caught fire and burned to waterline.  She sits off the mouth of Sturgeon River on Portage Lake.

This 254 foot steel barge struck a reef during a violent gale near Eagle Harbor. A companion barge, the Transport, also sank in the gale and is located about 110 yards inshore from the St. Joseph. Both wrecks lie broken and flattened out in shallow water ranging from 25 to 35 feet.

Searching for Copper Harbor Light to guide them to port on a dark, snowy night, the City of Superior finally found it - running aground just offshore.  Too far ashore to be pulled free, a rising northern gale broke her in two at the middle.  Much of her cargo was eventually recovered.

It is unclear if weather, navigational issues, or blinding smoke caused this propeller to ground on Sawtooth Reef.  After 3 days of lighering of her flour cargo, rising winds caused her back to break.  Much of her gear was salvaged, but what remains may be mixed with that of the nearby James Pickands.

The Fern, a relatively unseaworthy tug or scow, was overwhelmed by a sudden storm while salvaging the wreck of the Colorado.  Her hull was found inverted, the bow still partially afloat, and still anchored to the wreck.  Her yawl-boat and crew of 5 were never found.
Striking rocks while trying to enter Eagle Harbor in a gale, she was a total loss.  Much of her wreckage was removed over time.
This small propeller excursion steamer burned at her dock, a total loss. She still sits just off the dock site.

Blinded by smoke from forest fires, the Pickands ran firmly onto Sawtooth Reef.  A few days later a gale broke her in half, and she eventually went to pieces.  Boilers and more are located high on the reef, with more in deeper water nearby.

Possibly the oldest known shipwreck on Lake Superior, the John Jacob Astor was lost September 21, 1844 near the dock of old Fort Wilkins. Built at Black River, Ohio in 1835, the Astor was the first commercial vessel on Lake Superior after being portaged around the rapids at Sault Ste Marie. After stranding, she could not be refloated before winter and broke up in the severe conditions. Her rigging and portable equipment were salvaged.
A small schooner was pounded to pieces just inside Eagle Harbor. Her wreckage is sometimes confused with that of the Gazelle, but her ribs, keel, and coal cargo identify her remains.

Loaded with coal, the Langham was anchored in the lee of the Keweenaw Peninsula off Bete Grise Bay when she burned to the waterline and settled in 105 feet of water. While her decks burned away, the hull remains intact with two boilers, her engine and a variety of equipment.
The Law, enroute to Duluth, broke her towline to the steamer Edward Hines and drove ashore, where she quickly went to pieces.  The crew took to the lifeboats and survived.

Looking for shelter at Portage Entry, the steel steamer Maplehurst was swept by huge seas and unable to make progress towards safety.  Rescuers were able get 9 crewmen to jump to their lifeboat, but the others remained with the ship as she lost power and drifted into the breakers. Their bodies were recovered as they washed ashore later. Too badly damaged for salvage, her remains were dynamited as a hazard to navigation.

In tow of the steamer Kalkaska, she broke loose in a gale and was blown ashore.  Later recovered, she was towed to Houghton but was found to be too badly damaged, so she was abandoned off the grounds of Michigan Technical University.

Not recognizing that the vessel had drifted after recovering a buoy, the Mesquite ran aground when she turned towards her next assigned pickup.  Not severely damaged at first, a lack of leadership among her damage control party combined with rising waves that further ground her hull on the rocks, her crew were taken off by a passing vessel.   Because of the time of year, she could not be removed before winter and she was damaged beyond repair. As she was a total loss, the Coast Guard agreed to the intentional sinking of the Mesquite as a dive site. Most of her equipment is still on deck. Part of the pilot house was removed during the sinking and is now located near the hull.

Upbound with the schooner-barge Matanzas in tow, she started leaking in a gale. She was run ashore to avoid sinking, but was pounded to pieces by the storm waves.  Her engine was salvaged and re-used in a new Davidson steamer in 1907.

She was unloading cargo when a gale hit.  She backed away from the dock but broke her propeller shaft, becoming helpless. She was driven onto the rocks and destroyed.  She had been portaged around the Sault rapids in 1853.
This small steamer caught fire and burned at Stringers Sawmill dock 100 yds east of Wrights Point then drifted to this site and sank.

Blinded by a furious snowstorm, the Scotia ran onto the rocks of Keweenaw Point, and later broke in two when the winds shifted.  Later salvagers removed much of her gear, and some of the hull.  She had been sold to new owners only the day before.

The 285 foot steel package freighter Tioga ran aground on Sawtooth Reef on November 26, 1919 during a winter storm. A gale followed shortly after the stranding and she went to pieces. Today, the ship's debris including her boilers and engine can be examined in 28 to 35 feet of water.
This tow-barge was lost along with her companinon barge City of St Joseph when they both found a jagged reef during bad weather.
Bursting into flames just after docking in Eagle Harbor, much of her cargo and baggage was recovered before she burned.  Her remains sit just off the Life Saving Station on a sandy bottom.

The small steamer was docked for repairs at Ripley when it was discovered ablaze one evening. Her owner believed it was deliberately set. She burned to a shell. The remains were later moved to West Hancock where she was damaged and sunk by ice in the spring.

The wooden steamer Wasaga was carrying a cargo of farm equipment when she burned to a total loss in Copper Harbor while taking shelter from a strong gale.  Mostly salvaged, some cargo can still be found at this site just off the Harbor House Restaurant.

This new steamer ran onto Sawtooth Reef on only her 5th trip since her launch.  Not badly damaged at first, over the next days waves drove her farther onto the rocks until she broke in the middle.  The initial salvage failed, but a year later 278 ft of her stern was recovered by Reid Wrecking of Sarnia, and was rebuilt as part of the steamer Sir Trevor Dawson.  The remaining bow sections washed off the reef into deeper water, now crushed flat at 40 ft.

The Alva Bradley, a three masted schooner, was lost in a gale on October 13, 1894 on the shoal at the south end of North Manitou Island. The wreck of the schooner was discovered by Dave Trotter in 1990. This largely intact wreck affords access to her cargo of steel billets and many maritime artifacts. Remains of her rigging and more artifacts lie about 200 yards northeast of the hull.
Sections of the hull and sides of this two-masted schooner lie off the southwest side of Pyramid Point.  Her anchors failed while she was taking shelter from a gale, and she broke up in the shallows.

This ocean-going freighter was built in 1922 as Arcadia and went through many other names until it became, in 1959, the Francisco Morazan. It was lost in a snowstorm on November 29, 1960 when the she ran aground on rocks off the south end of South Manitou Island. The broken hull now rests in very shallow water a few hundred yards from the shore. She is partially filled with sand, and remains of the hull protrude above water, visible from the mainland.
This large propeller was driven onto Sleeping Bear Point and destroyed in a storm.  A large portion of her hull washed ashore in the 1950's, and remains can still be seen from atop the dunes.

The Moore was a 103 foot schooner that stranded at Gull Point, South Manitou Island on September 10, 1907. Her wreckage is scattered in shallow water, 10 to 12 feet deep.  Some think this wreckage may be part of the Annie Vought, a much larger vessel.
A brig that ran aground during a storm on 1857. Her remains lie in 5 to 15 feet of water near Sleeping Bear Point, not far from the General Taylor.
The Montauk stranded on North Manitou Island in a gale. The remains of the 137 foot schooner rest on rocks in two sections.

This 133 foot long wooden steamer stranded just north of Pyramid Point on October 29, 1917. She went to pieces and her wreckage now rests in 6 to 12 feet of water.  Her steam engine, propshaft, and sometimes a boiler are covered and uncovered by the shifting sands.
This 132 foot brig was built in 1855 at Buffalo, New York.  In November, 1869 she stranded on North Manitou Island. The debris of the ship and her cargo of bricks now lie in 8 to 10 feet of water.

Launched in 1888 as the May Durr, the Three Brothers was a 162 foot long wooden steamer. She beached on September 27, 1911 on the lee side of South Manitou Island. She was abandoned to the weather and the combination of winter storms and shifting sand quickly buried her. In 1996 the weather shifted the sands revealing a nearly perfect shipwreck, easily accessible from the beach. While her bow is broken, the stern is intact. The hull is filled with sand.

The 235 foot long wooden steamer Walter L. Frost was lost November 4, 1903 when she ran aground on South Manitou Island. She is now broken up, largely because the Francisco Morazan ran aground on top of her. The Frost, being in shallow water of about 12 feet offers explorers an ideal view of her remaining hull, boilers and related artifacts.

The Arctic was caught in fog and ran onto the east side of Lighthouse Island in the Huron Islands. The ship's bow is in the gap between the Lighthouse Island and the small island offshore.  Part of her engine and hull are in shallow water on the west side, but portions can be found as deep as 105 feet.

The Kershaw went on the rocks in a storm while towing two schooner- barges on September 29, 1895. The 223 foot long wooden steamer lost power and her crew was rescued by the Marquette Life Saving Service. The Kershaw went to pieces in shallow water, where her boiler, hull, and debris remains.

This ship was lost while struggling to enter Marquette harbor with a cargo of logs, coming to rest about 800 feet off Lighthouse Point near downtown Marquette.  Her engine, boiler and machinery were salvaged. Three large parts of the hull and her large rudder remain in about 40 feet of water. Divers will also see tools, fasteners and piping scattered in more shallow water.
She stranded and broke up on December 4, 1869. Her framing and planking are in about 10 feet of water inside an old dock area, and make an easy novice dive or snorkeling opportunity.

The Florida met her fate in a blizzard when she was crushed against the Marquette docks, with the loss of one life. The ship's remains are now in shallow water and covered with shifting sands. Her framing and planking are just outside the cribs of an old dock.

Located near Huron Island's lighthouse is the wreckage of the 207 foot long George Nester. She stranded there in a storm on April 30, 1909 and seven of her crew died. The schooner-barge has water depths ranging from 20 to more than 100 feet.
Stranded in a blinding snowstorm, she broke up in the shallows.  Three main sections of hull remain, along with scattered debris.

The Sheadle left her rudder and a propeller blade here when she backed into a rocky reef. The vessel itself was recovered and sailed until scrapping in 1980.  Nearby is the "Iron Man", a human-shaped water intake for a long-defunct charcoal plant.
An abandoned fish tug, she lies across the south side of Thill's Dock in Marquette's Inner Harbor.  Nearby is the fish tug Superior.
Losing her anchors while riding out a gale, she broke up in the shallows.  Stacks of bricks remain in the hold, around the centerboard well.

This 137 foot sailing vessel stranded, then slid into deeper water one and one half miles southeast of the largest of the Huron Islands. She was running in a heavy smoke/fog on September 18, 1898 when the disaster occurred. Today, divers will find the remains of the Southwest scattered in 100 feet of water.  Sometimes mistakenly recorded as South West.
Another abandoned fish tug, she lies on the north side of the Association Dock, across the slip from the Marion L.

The schooner Amranth was used as a towbarge at the end of her career.  She was driven ashore while in tow of the steamer John H. Pauly and became a total loss, being pounded to pieces.  Her crew was saved by the Pauly.  The wreck lies mostly buried in the lake bottom.
An old wooden steamer, she was stripped, then burned and scuttled well offshore.  Her propeller and various small artifacts remain.

A small steamer, she had 3 schooner-barges in tow and was running empty when fire broke out.  The crew cut loose the barges, and was able to keep the engines running long enough to beach her.  The crew was taken off by a lifeboat from one of the barges, and everyone escaped safely.  Engines and other equipment remain just below the water surface.

This 3 year old ship was lost in �The Great Storm� of 1913 that also claimed the Regina. After the storm cleared, she was found floating upside, and eventually sank in 64 feet of water. Today she rests upside down on the bottom with the hull collapsing.

Raised and rebuilt as a scow after spending seven years on the bottom of the St. Mary's River, she was in tow of the Tempest in heavy seas on October 30, 1906 when she foundered off Forestville. She now sits with her stern broken and scattered. The bow is intact with much equipment distributed about.
This wooden freighter collided with the much larger steel freighter W.H. Gilbert, sinking quickly.  She was raised but found to be too badly damaged, so she was scuttled in the open lake.
She foundered with her cargo of iron ore in 1876.  Much of the machinery was recovered shortly after it sank.  Located in 2001.
Collided with the Thomas Parsons off Lexington, MI.  The surviving crew jumped onto the Parsons, but were unable to save their friends.  The cargo of pig iron was later salvaged.

Foundered in a storm with a cargo of coal in 1864. Discovered in 1957, her bow anchors and wheel were removed, one anchor sits outside the Port Sanilac Historical Museum. She sits upright with her forward hull mostly intact, while the stern has collapsed.  Features a stove, bilge pump, winches and windlass.

The Strong was towing the schooner-barge Our Son, both loaded with white pine lumber, when she caught on fire.  The barge was cut loose and the crew took to the lifeboats.  Meanwhile, a passing steamer saw the fire and came close enough to put a line aboard and tow her into shallow water where they fought the fire until their own vessel was scorched.  The machinery was removed the following year, and in 1909 the wreck was flattened with dynamite.   What remains is upright with the keel and some decking still intact in about 28 feet of water.

properties.VesselType: Built as Brig, converted to Schooner barge
properties.Description: Caught fire and burned to a total loss while under tow.  The remains were dynamited as a hazard to navigation.  Features a windlass, knees & more.

Various spellings abound for this vessel.  After a stop in Port Huron, where she was arrested until outstanding bills were paid, the Breden headed up the lake bound for Bay City, in tow of the Winslow.  She was heavily loaded with 600 tons of coal.  A gale came up and she fell apart under the strain, her bow tearing loose from the remaining hull. The Captain and one other crewman made it to shore.
She went ashore north of Lexington in a storm.  Salvage was attempted, and her hulk was later burned as well. Scattered wreckage remains.

This veteran tugboat was being towed home from Rockport where she had been helping salvage the Monrovia.  She started leaking while the crewman aboard was sleeping. Although the towing tug tried pumping her out, she continued filling until they were forced to cut her loose and watch her sink.  She is upright and intact in 92 feet of water. Her wheelhouse, with her wheel still in place, is a favorite with photographers.

This wooden steamer was launched at Buffalo in 1856 and was lost to heavy seas on October 14, 1876. She lies close to the Checotah and is upright but very broken up. Her unique oscillating steam engines are exposed to view and are of special interest. Part of a wooden hogging arch is still in place. She has many tools and much gear present.

The North Star was lost after a collision in the fog with her sister ship, the Northern Queen.  She was bound for Duluth with a load of grain and shingles when she was struck and sank southeast of Port Sanilac. She rests in two pieces. Her pilothouse is intact and her engine and boilers are in place.

After a troubled 14 year career as a passenger and freight boat, she was converted to a lumbar barge.  She struck on some rocks, breaking the towline, and then quickly went to pieces.  Her stern section is relatively intact, with portions of the hogging arches and paddle guards still evident.

Built in 1907, the 250 foot long steel freighter Regina fell prey to the The Great Storm of 1913 and went missing with all hands, and was located 1986. The ship rests upside down on the bottom in about 80 feet of water.  There is a 56 foot hole in the hull that permits entry to the hold area.
Bound from Cheboygan to Tonawanda NY, broke away from towing steamer in storm. Information provided by Noble Odyssey Foundation.

This small tugboat is important as the first steel tug on the Great Lakes. She had a long career as a working tug on the Lakes, but at 57 feet she was no match for a severe gale on December 13, 1920. Her steel hull rests upright, with a slight list to starboard. The depth of water is 45 feet although the Sport rises up about 20 feet off the bottom. Divers find her intact with an abundance of tools and relics scattered about the wreck site. The Sport has received the distinction of being the first Michigan shipwreck with her own Michigan Historical Marker placed on her.

Located in 2017 by Rick Ball, work continues to identify this small schooner.  Measured at 117x26x10, she contains a centerboard box, the port anchor is on the bottom below the cat-head.  Dead-eyes are still in place on the rail, while much of the deck has collapsed.  Part of port side is displace at an angle, the bowsprit is present bu turned and tipped downwards.  Cargo appears to have been coal.  Anchor windlass,  forward capstan, and centerboard winch are present, along with some cookware.

Tise crane is all that remains of a crane and wooden barge that sank in the 1980s in about 50 feet of water. The Crane and Barge was under tow after delivering a load of steel to Benton Harbor and enroute to Grand Haven when she filled with water and sank. The crane's boom struck the bottom and is bent at a sharp angle lying on the bottom. Many gobies and small fish now inhabit the machinery and works of this site.
An small, unnamed fireboat, very open and easy to dive.

Originally a Chesapeake Bay Oyser Dredge, this sailing vessel serve as a commercial fishing vessel and later a passenger pleasure sailing boat. She sank at her dock in in 1980's, and was supposedly towed out to her present location.

A 135 foot schooner, the Havana was lost on October 3, 1887. After encountering heavy seas, she sank slowly and settled into 50 feet of water. The Havana has broken apart leaving many construction details exposed. The hull, keelson, centerboard, hanging knees are exposed to view.

The lumber schooner Rockaway was lost in a storm off South Haven on November 19, 1891 while sailing from Ludington to Benton Harbor. The wreck site has been the subject of several archeology studies and very good drawings of her remains exist. She now sits in 70 feet of water.

properties.VesselType: Gas Screw Yacht, sometimes Cargo Carrier
properties.Description: Originally built as the Idler, renamed Paul Resse II in 1933, and then Verano in 1935, this 92’ yacht foundered in heavy seas on her way to Holland, Michigan for an overhaul and repainting. She now sits in about 55 feet of water, featuring two large engines and dashboard with the keys still in the ignition switch.

A small, custom-built barge used to dig the trench for a water intake on Mackinac Island, she sank while being towed back to St. Ignace.  Builder Glashaw received several patents for clam-bucket control mechanism

The three-masted schooner Albemarle was driven ashore just west of Point Au Sable, today's Point Nipigon, in a November storm after only 4 months after  into service.  Much of her gear was recovered that month, and her iron ore was largely recovered the following year.  Shifting sands cover and uncover this wreck, but the centerboard box still rises from the bottom surrounded by a pile of iron ore.  This site is frequently viewed by kayaks and is a great snorkle site, but is far enough offshore to require a boat for access.

This Canadian schooner was, with the J.A. Smith,  part of a tow that was left at anchor in the western Straits of Mackinac while the towing vessel, the steamer Mattawan, went to refuel at Cheboygan.  A storm arose and both vessels were blown ashore and broken up.  Ice and waves have reduced this site to scattered boards for snorkelers and kayaks to find and view.

properties.Builder: Abram Smith Shipyard, James Navagh builder
properties.Description: The Anna Smith was a wooden steamer that began leaking and was run aground off Cordwood Point in November 1889.  After the 2nd mate was lost while trying to reach shore on a raft to report the wreck, the crew spent a cold night waiting for rescue.  They started a fire in the coal bunker to keep warm, but neglected to extinguish the fire when they were taken off by a tug a day later.  The fire grew and consumed the entire vessel above the waterline.  Much machinery was recovered, but her boilers and lower timbers remain, and can be accessed from shore.   The Ann Smith's captain, Timese Lamay, was also captain of the Eber Ward when it was cut by ice in the Straits in 1909, making him the only captain to lose two vessels in the Straits of Mackinac.

This small schooner was carrying a cargo of large sandstone blocks from Jacobsville, MI on the Keweenaw when she anchored behind St Helena Island to wait out a gale.  The winds shifted and her anchor lines parted, driving her onto the rocks off Gros Cap.  Over time the upper works were washed away, but the lower hull was held to the reef by the stone blocks, and make a great shallow dive and snorkeling site, with the blocks also visible for kayakers.  Two portions of the decking lie nearby, but otherwise only cables and small fittings can be located.   No public access nearby, ask for permission or approach by boat.

The propeller Canisteo was involved in a collision with a sailing vessel near Waugoshance Light, and her capain ran her into shallow water in an attempt to save her.   A rising storm destroyed the ship before salvage could be attempted. This is the same storm that sank the Alpena in lower Lake Michigan.  Much of the hull is ground up by ice, but debris lies scattered about the entire area.

This sturdy steel freighter has the dubious distinction of being a rare steel vessel to be sunk by a wooden ship, after colliding with the Joseph Hurd just south of Gray's Reef Passage.  The Hurd was towed to safety with a badly-damaged bow, and a major salvage effort was made to raise the Cayuga.  Chains were slung under the hull, and a number of pontoons attached in order to lift her.  One the first attempt, she was well off the bottom when a forward chain snapped, and the boat fell back to bottom and broke her hull.  Further work was futile.  The stern of the wreck is intact, with several large pontoons still attached on either side, and the bow of the vessel largely collapsed and broken up.  A wooden work barge sits on the bottom off the port side.

Built in 1927, the Cedarville is the third largest freighter lost on the Great Lakes (after the Edmund Fitzgerald and the Carl Bradley). This 600 foot ship sank in a tragic accident on May 7, 1965 in Lake Huron. An ocean-going Norwegian freighter collided midships with the Cedarville in foggy  weather. Ten men died when she rolled and sank in 37 degree water. The Cedarville lies on her starboard side broken nearly in two in 105 feet of water. Because she is partly inverted, divers can become disoriented on her. The hull can be reached at about 40 feet. The bow and stern sections are generally both buoyed. Divers can visit the pilothouse and large holds. The unloading boom lies along the hull on the bottom. The stern features the galley and crew quarters.

This dump barge was located by Chuck Feltner in 1982. It lies inverted in 55 ft of water just east of St Helena Island.  It probably belonged to Durocher Dock and Dredge of Cheboygan and was lost in the 1940's.

The schoner Circassian stranded on White Shoal in a gale and blinding snowstorm in November 1860.  The vessel was washed completely by waves and broke in the middle, forcing the crew to abaondon her and row to Hog Island, where they survived for two weeks before being spotted and rescued. This site is completely broken up, heavily salvaged for gear, and much timber was scavenged for furniture-making purposes.

The Colonel Ellsworth spent the fall and winter of 1895 ashore at Whitefish Point, and was recovered and repaired in 1896. She had only been back to work for a short time when she was involved in a collision with the Emily Maxwell off Waugoshance Light in a gale and rainstorm.  The crew escaped as the Ellsworth sank in 80 ft.  Her anchors and usable equipment were later salvaged.  Masts and other gear lie about the wreck.

The 213 foot long Eber Ward was built in 1888. She was cut by ice and sank on April 9, 1909 in Lake Michigan. She is upright and mostly intact and is an excellent example of a classic wooden bulk freighter. Her deck can be reached at 105 feet and the bottom at 150 feet. Her engines and boilers provide items of interest for divers. The holds can be fairly easily penetrated by experienced divers. Her port bow has a large and unique “mushroom” anchor.  A conventional woodstock anchor rests on her starboard bow. One of her lifeboats is overturned on the bottom off her starboard stern.

Due to conflicting news reports, this wooden schooner was long believed to be the St. Andrew, lost in a collision with the Peshtigo. However, in 2019 the real St. Andrew and Peshtigo were found together in deep water off Beaver Island. Research is ongoing to determine the true identity of this wreck.  An 1857 coin was found in the step of the foremast.

The Bay City built Fred McBrier was lost in a collision in October 1890 with a cargo of iron ore.  The stern is largely intact, including the engine and boilers, but the forward deck and port side of the hull have shifted to one side.  A mast lies on the bottom off the bow.  Much forward gear, including an anchor and the capstan have been salvaged but the rudder and propeller remain in the 100 ft depths.

The Genesee Chief was built as a twin-screw propeller, was rebuilt as a single-screw, then as an unrigged barge, and eventually as a two-mast schooner.  She became severely waterlogged and was left at the  Millard Olds docks in Cheboygan in 1891.  Eventually she was raised from the bottom and towed into Duncan Bay to be abandoned near the dropoff, off Cheboygan State Park.  She is a great snorkeling site, with many fish hiding within the recesses of her remaining timbers.

The Clay was a brig that was driven high up onto the sands west of Point Au Sable, today's Point Nipigon.  She was too far up to recover, and broke down piece by piece over time.  Her remains are often covered in sand, but portions reappear at irregular intervals.  The site is only about 300 yards from the Albemarle.

The propeller Islander was used as a general cargo vessel, a Mackinac Island ferry, and a lumber boat before being abandoned in the Cheboygan River.  The hulk was raised and relocated to Duncan Bay to make room for the Coast Guard station where the cutter Mackinaw resides today.  The Islander lies along the sandy edge of the drop-off on the Duncan City side of the bay, just north of the channel to the Duncan Bay Yacht Club.

This Canadian schooner was, with the Anglo Saxon, part of a tow that was left at anchor in the western Straits of Mackinac while the towing vessel, the steamer Mattawan, went to refuel at Cheboygan.  A storm arose and both vessels were blown ashore and broken up.  Ice and waves have reduced this site to scattered boards for snorkelers and kayaks to find and view.

The J.H. Outwaite was a bulk steamer in the iron ore trade.  In the Great Storm of 1905, she was downbound off Mackinaw when she lost her steering, and eventually she grounded off today's Point Nipigon. The crew built a fire to warm themselves through the night, and then made their way to shore in the morning.  Their fire flared up after they departed and burned the vessel to the waterline.  The anchors, engines, and boilers were salvaged, and the shifting sands cover much of the wreck.

The schooner J.H. Tiffany was struck by the propeller Milwaukee on a dark night in November 1859.  She was badly damaged, and the crew tried to beach her on Skillagallee.  The ship sank too quickly, and they crew had to take to the rigging as the yawl boat was badly damaged.  The survivors were rescued by the Free State after she had recovered the crew of the Milwaukee, sinking at the collision site.

The L.B. Coates was a small schooner built in Saugatuck, MI, to to carry lumber.  Her namesdake, Capt. Linsford Baines Coates, partnered with George Arnold to form Coates & Arnold Steamship Company, predecessor of the Arnold Transit Company of Mackinac Island.  The tired old vessel was abandoned at the Whitehall Lumber Company dock in Cheboygan.  It burned at least once, and slowly deteriorated along with the docks, until nothing was left above water.  Today a length of her keel with cross-timbers lies just below the surface, near the outlet of the Little Black River.  This site is very near to the Myrtie Ross, and both can be visited on the same trip.

The Landbo foundered near Pt Au Sable (Point Nipigon) with a  cargo of coal, was recovered, raised, and used as a ligher, and then sold to the Lund Marine business in Cheboygan to be used as a dry dock.  She burned before this happened and she was a abandoned at the Olds dock (where the CG Cutter Mackinaw now docks) and was later moved to the east edge of the river channel just before it meets the lake.

The Leviathan was a famous wrecking tug based in Cheboygan, involved in the recovery of many stranded or injured vessels.  She burned at her Cheboygan River dock and settled to the bottom.  The remains were raised and relocated in Duncan Bay, very near the Genesee Chief, and are another prime kayak and snorkel site off Cheboygan State Park.

The schooner Lucy Clark was loading cordwood at Cross Village when winds rose and she was blown onto shore.  The tug SS Coe from Milwaukee came and pulled her off, and was taking her to Sturgeon Bay when her steering broke and she was forced to turn back.  A gale came up, and they cut the Clark loose to run for shelter, while the Clark went to anchor.  The Clark crew headed for shore in the yawl, and the Clark capsized and sank, while the crew's boat also capsized near shore with the loss of 3 lives.

The M Stalker was  two-masted schooner that normally carried iron ore.  She was named for her first Captain, Malcomb Stalker (not Martin).  In November 1886 she was at anchor off Mackinaw City, riding out a gale, when she was struck by a schooner barge towed by a passing steamer.  She released her anchor and attempted to make sail, but were forced to take to their boats as she sank.  The hull lies in 80-100 ft of water, with the transom off, but masts and spars lie alongside.  Her headgear was damaged in the original collision, but the deck has several easy penetrations for divers.

The graceful, 141 foot bark Maitland was built in Goderich, Ontario and launched in 1861. She was converted to American ownership in 1867 and was carrying a load of corn when she collided with two ships on June 11, 1871. She survived a glancing blow by the first but was struck hard on her starboard side by the second, and she sank quickly in 85 feet of water. Her masts are gone but her hull is intact except for the impact site. Visiting divers can see her windlass and many deck fittings. Her cabin roof lies inverted on the bottom at her starboard stern.
While tied to the loading dock, the crew was awakened at 9:30-10 pm by smoke from the hold.  The dock and piled lumber was also destroyed.

The propeller Milwaukee was in a collision with the schooner J.H. Tiffany during the night of November 29, 1859.   The Milwakee struck the Tiffany abreast the foremast, badly damaging the schooner, but was badly injured herself when the Tiffany swung around as the Milwaukee withdrew.  Both vessels sank.  The Milwaukee was salvaged, with her engines and boilers being recovered.  Much damage was done to the vessel to get at the engines.

The steamer Minneapolis began life as a passenger and package-freight steamer. First placed in service in 1873, she was converted to a freight-only steamer in 1888 by the removal of her upper deck cabins. On April 4, 1894 she was cut by ice and foundered in Lake Michigan. The location is just southwest of the Mackinac Bridge’s south tower in 124 feet of water. Her deck and engines can be reached at about 80 feet. Her bow is broken open and her stern has begun to come apart. Most of her main deck is collapsing. Divers can explore her engine and boiler and her deck equipment like her windlass. The rudder has detached from the hull and rests on the bottom. Game fish frequently inhabit the site. Currents can be very strong near the shipwreck.

Myrtie M Ross was another small, retired steamer, abandoned at her Cheboygan dock when she failed boiler inspections.  She slowly broke apart over time, and the remaining timbers lie along the line of dock timbers off Little Black River, just east of the L.B. Coates.  This is another good kayak and snorkel site.

properties.BuildPlace: Bangor Township, Michigan near Bay City
properties.Description: The Northwest was a four-mast schooner barge that was cut by ice in April 1898.  She sank while being towed to shallow water in an attempt to save her.  This wreck is broken up onto itself by salvage attempts and wave action, but plenty of artifacts remain for divers to view.  It is relatively shallow, in 65 ft, and is in spring is covered with spawing whitefish and perch.  A small boiler and steam winch for working the sails is located forward of amidships.

This brig was reported stranded west of Mackinaw City in 1854. The remains were moved and abandoned, and are known locally as "George's Wreck" for the person that located them near his home.  The remaining timbers of this shallow site are good for snorkeling, kayaks, and beginning divers alike.

The Persevearance was  a two-masted schooner that was lost in the Straits of Mackinac South Channel in a collision with the schooner Grey Eagle.  She went down with a cargo of wheat, but her crew were all saved by the Grey Eagle.  The site lies directly in the modern vessel track and so is not buoyed.  The hull is buried into the bottom nearly to the railing, with the stern transom lying nearby.  You must broadcast a warning to shipping before diving this site, and avoid it in poor visibility.

The 203-ft. steamer Peshtigo stranded on Mackinac Island's Mission Point in a 1908 storm, and was broken up by ice and wave action.  Much of her hull is covered now, but portions can still be located in the shallows between shore and Red Buoy #2, and along the east edge of the drop-off.

The large, four-masted schooner Richard Winslow was reduced to use as a tow barge when it was lost in September 1898.  It was carrying iron ore from Escanaba in tow behind the steamer Inter Ocean when she began leaking, and the crew was taken off as the Winslow settled to the bottom off White Shoal.  The remains were dynamited in 1902 to remove the obstruction.  Wreckage is scattered and broken up.

This small, 110 foot brig, built in 1848, was lost in a storm in Lake Michigan with all hands on September 20, 1856. She sits upright with a fgurehead still gracing her prow. Over the years before it was made illegal, many of her artifacts were removed by divers. Still, she is an imposing site to visit and is very popular with less experienced divers since she sits in 80 feet of water and her deck can be reached at 70 feet.

The Sea Gull was a wrecking tug owned by Captain James Reid, a noted salvor of the time.  She was towing a disabled steamer in Lake Huron when fire broke out below decks, quickly forcing the crew to abandon her.  A passing vessel came to their aid, putting out the fire and moving the hulk to the shores of Bois Blanc Island near the lighthouse, where it was abandoned.

This shipwreck was discovered in 2002 off South Graham Shoal in Lake Huron. Built in 1863, she had been converted to a schooner-barge when she foundered . Sitting upright in 125 feet of water, the William Young has all of her fttings and gear intact. Her bow is split open and her chains and anchors are spilled onto the lake ﬂoor. She was carrying a cargo of coal that still fills her holds. Her wheel, deadeyes, pulleys, and other equipment are scattered about the wreck, with one mast on the bottom alongside, and another nearby in deeper water.

The wooden steamer William H. Barnum was built in 1873. She was lost on April 3, 1894 � the day before the Minneapolis. She, too, was cut by ice and then foundered in about 75 feet of water in Lake Huron just off Freedom, MI. The bow is intact and the chain locker area is sufficiently open to permit fairly easy penetration. What remains of her deck and engine can be reached at about 50 feet. The hull is intact except for the stern, as it was dynamited to recover the rudder for display in St. Ignace.

This small schooner was caught by a northwest gale at the Callam Company dock in Cecil Bay, just west of McGulpin Point.  She was blown ashore, broken up, and went to pieces.  The scattered wreckage can be viewed along with the remains of the dock piles, about 1000 ft west of the Carp Lake River outlet.

After a collision with the Steemer Philadelphia, the Philadelphia began towing her towards shore but she took on water too quickly and sank. The Philadelphia picked up the survivors, but then that ship was also discovered to be sinking, and everyone reached safety via lifeboat.
A steamer that started leaking and sank, she has a distinctive engine for divers to explore.
Information provided by Noble Odyssey Foundation
A large 322-foot double-deck schooner, the Chicamauga foundered on September 12, 1919. She sits in about 32 feet of water just east of Harbor Beach and is very accessible to novice divers.
Information provided by Noble Odyssey Foundation
An old schooner, she burned while in layup inside Harbor Beach harbor.

This 1880's era barge was located in 74 feet of water, just outside of Grindstone City. The wreck is frequently visited by many game fish and usually has excellent visibility. The chain and winch mechanism for opening the large dump doors are still present.

The steel steamer Glenorchy was struck  and sunk by the Leonard P Miller on October 29, 1924. She is a large wreck at 356 feet long. She sits in 120 feet of water and can be penetrated by experienced divers.

The oldest known wreck in the Thumb Preserve is the Goliath, a package and bulk freighter. She exploded and burned on September 13, 1848. Her main features are an upright engine, boiler, stove and unique early propellers. They can be examined in about 104 feet of water.

This wooden steamer was built as a barge to be paired with the steamer Iron Duke, and was later converted to steam.  She was lost in a storm on October 4, 1904 when she began leaking through the propeller stuffing box. She lies broken in 129 feet of water. Whitefish are frequent visitors to this wreck, swimming around her large piles of coal.

Lost in a storm on September 3, 1879, the 139 foot long steamer Bertschy sits in 8 feet of water southeast of the Grindstone City Harbor. This is a great shore dive for beginning divers and snorkelers, with many game fish usually seen.
Information provided by Noble Odyssey Foundation
Information provided by Noble Odyssey Foundation
Information provided by Noble Odyssey Foundation
Information provided by Noble Odyssey Foundation

In a collision with the steamer Albany in 1893, she attempted to tow her victim to safety, but both vessels eventually went to the bottom.  She is upright in 120 feet of water. The wreck is mostly intact with her cargo of heating and cooking stoves resting on the deck and scattered on the lake ?oor.
Only lower hull wreckage remains of this steamer, wrecked when trying to shelter.  Machinery was salvaged shortly afterwards.
A two-masted schooner, she sprang a leak and was run aground below Black River.  Only the lower hull remains.
A huge sailing ship, the American Union stranded ashore at Thompson's Harbor in a storm.
One of the North Point wrecks, she stranded and broke up here in 1904 along with her consort barge, the John T. Johnson.

Launched as a railroad carferry and later converted to a bulk freight barge, this huge wooden vessel was pushed onto the rocks of North Point.  Her sidewalls are reported to be intact, and her steering quadrant is exposed.
This barge is sunk next to the Nordmeer without any known cause.  She seems to be largely intact.
Abandoned after it pounded on the piers, only lower frames, keel, and some planking remain.
Stranded while trying to deliver supplies for the lighthouse and resident fisherman, she was stripped, and later broke up in winter. storms.
Veteran of 5-6 strandings, this tired old schooner-barge was abandoned off Crawford's Quarry and allowed to sink.
An old tugboat, she burned to the waterline and sank.  Ice and waves inverted her, exposing her prop to divers.
Only a day after being lightered and pulled off of Black River Reef, she grounded near North Point. Fire broke out and she burned to the waterline.
This wooden steamer sprang a leak and went down northeast of Thunder Bay Island.  Her decking is gone but the hull and much more remain.
She grounded north of Forty Mile Point, and later sank just offshore near the north end of Hammond Bay.
This large freighter sits upside-down on the bottom after a collision with the Quincy Shaw.
Another steamer-turned-barge, she was wrecked in a botched salvage. Keelsons and frames remain.
A small tug, she was scuttled in Swan Bay in 1923.

This small wooden schooner was struck by the bark Newsboy on November 18, 1871 and sank. The Allen came to rest intact on a sandy bottom in about 95 feet of water. Divers can view evidence of the collision on her port side.  Divers can see her windlass, anchor chains and rudder.

Stranded on North Point Reef near Middle Island in a northeast gale, salvagers worked frantically to recover her, but when winds shifted to southeast, lifesavers took off her crew and she broke apart, drifting off to deeper water.
Broken in two after being wrecked in a storm, features a rudder and iron ore cargo.
This steamer stranded on North Point in 1872 and broke up. Her remains are now mixed with the Blanchard and Johnson.
This old vessel began leaking through her seams in a storm, and sank about 4 miles offshore.

The Grecian struck bottom near Detour and nearly sank.  She was salvaged, and was being towed down the lake for repairs when her patches failed and she sank off Thunder Bay Island. Her bow area is intact, but the decks have collapsed over much of her length, standing up again only near her stern houses.  She sports a triple expansion engine, boiler, decks and cargo holds. There is a spare propeller blade on one deck ahead of the engine room.
A work barge used for dredging, off North Point.
This wooden wreck lies east of the marina and breakwall, featuring a huge keelson and stern post. She stranded while in tow of the David W. Rust.
A 3-masted schooner, she broke up on Black River Island and went to pieces.
This Bay City-built wooden steamer stranded on a reef off Thunder Bay Light while carrying a cargo of coal, going to pieces over the following days.
A two-masted lumber-hauler, she struck a crib and sank. She was relocated in 1989 to a safer location.
A small schooner wrecked near the mouth of the river, only the lower hull remains.

In tow of the John Eddy, she began leaking and broke her towline while crossing the mouth of Saginaw Bay.  Her crew escaped in her boats, while she drifted off and sank off Greenbush. She was located by the wrecking tug Johsnton in July 1896.
Another North Point wreck, this schooner-barge was in tow of the Blanchard and came ashore with her towing vessel.

Just off Forty Mile Point Light, the Fay began leaking in a fierce storm, and was grounded in the shallows to save her.  The ship was pounded beyond salvage by the waves.  Portions of the hull are on shore, with larger portions just offshore in clear water, great for snorkeling and kayaks.
Abandoned in 1903
One of eight schooners blown ashore in the area in the same storm, this was formerly known as the North Point wreck. The port side is intact.
Abandoned after a full life of strandings and sinkings.
A small steamer that burned at the Alger Smith dock at Black River.  The bow and cabins are gone but the stern is complete.
The steamer Lehigh ran her down off Thunder Bay Island. Her coal cargo was partially salvaged, collapsing her decks, but the centerboard remains.
A fire started near her boiler while unloading at the Black River dock.  Dock workers pushed her away from the dock and allowed her to sink nearby.

This old schooner had recently been condemned when she was driven ashore in a storm.  She was in such poor shape that the loss of ship & cargo was only $800.  Several sources have her off Nine Mile Point below Cheboygan.
This John Alden - designed schooner exploded and burned north of Stoneport.
A popular coastal side-wheeler, she burned while southbound, but most on board were rescued.  Her charred remains include some machinery.
A wooden steamer, she burned to a total loss and settled in the shallows.  A good site for glass-bottom boats and snorkeling.

This 430 foot ocean going freighter was lost in a collision on June 25, 1959 while transporting a cargo of steel. Her hull now rests in 80 to 130 feet of water. Unlike the typical laker, she is built along the lines of a �Liberty ship� with her cabins located mid-deck. She was heavily salvaged and her bow has been twisted to one side to permit access to her holds.
The sidewheel steamer Montana caught fire and burned to the waterline on September 7, 1914.   Major features are the double-steeple compound engine and the remains of her huge hogging arches.
This work barge was used for a number of harbor and dock improvements but was eventually abandoned in Issacson Bay. She now lies in pieces.
This vessel is now believed to be the William H. Stevens
This small sidewheeler grounded in fog between North Point and Sugar Island.  Remains are broken and scattered.
A coal-laden steamer, she sank after colliding with the larger steel freighter William R. Linn.  Ends of wreck are intact, with the middle broken up.

A German freighter, she was running without a Great Lakes Pilot when she tried to go on the wrong side of the buoy marking a shoal.  She was not too badly damaged at first, but the grounding was followed by the storm that sank the Daniel J. Morrell, damaging her beyond repair.  Portions of the hull remained above water for over 40 years, but it is now all hidden just beneath the waves.
A sidewheel steamer converted to a barge, she stranded and became a total loss. Located at the north end of Harrisville Marina.
A small steamer hauling pulpwood, she grounded on a reef west of Thunder Bay Island and broke up.
Carrying a cargo of coal at the end of a line from the Zillah, her cargo burst into flames, and she burned to the waterline over 3 days, finally sinking.

Loaded with limestone for a lower-lake destination, the Flint was anchored while waiting for weather when a fire broke out.  She sits upright on the bottom, burned down to the level of the cargo, with some artifacts to be found nearby.
Two-master wrecked in Bell Bay with a salt cargo. Only the starboard side and bilge remain.
Dragging anchors while trying to shelter from a storm, she stranded and then caught fire on Middle Island before breaking up.
Only the lower hull remains of this brig after she was blown ashore in a violent storm with an iron ore cargo.
A gravel-dredge barge broken into three pieces, featuring a steam crane boom, boiler, winches, steam engine and anchor.

A wooden passenger and freight steamer, only recently converted from a sailing vessel, she foundered just off Alpena.  Portions of the hull, as well as boiler parts, propeller shaft, and other small artifacts remain.
A barge used in the salvage work on the Grecian, she foundered and went to the bottom about a mile away.  She features a wheelhouse on her stern.
A small schooner loaded with coal, she sprang a leak and sank, her crew taking to the boats and rowing to Cheboygan.
This loaded schooner foundered in a storm with her cargo of grindstones, taking all hands down with her.
She started leaking, and foundered NNE of Thunder Bay Island, her crew was rescued by a passing steamer.
Abandoned after being stripped, allowed to sink in the shallows.
Driven onto Black River Reef in a storm, she broke up and sank well offshore.
Built as a 3-mast schooner, she was cut down to a barge. She swamped and sank in a storm while being towed by the Isabella Boyce.
Only the flattened lower hull remains of this vessel that ran aground.  Long thought to be the Nellie Garner.
A fish tug wrecked in a storm, only a some stern deadwood and broken propeller and shaft remain.
A former steamer, this converted barge strandes a mile east of the cement plant with a partial cargo of limestone.
This small steamer was running light when she collided with the William Livingston.  The boilers and engines remain upright, and much of the hull is intact, with an anchor and chain still at the bow.
This steel bulk freighter was lost in the “Armistice Day” storm of 1940. She now lies broken into two parts in about 36 to 45 feet of water near Pentwater.

A classic lumber-hauling schooner-barge, the Brightie was 182 feet long. She was built in 1868 and was lost in August 1928 when she foundered carrying a load of pulpwood. Her cargo and broken remains are in about 70 feet of water north of Whitehall.
A small tugboat, sitting upright on the bottom.

A 1930 Bucyrus-Erie steam crane was on a barge being towed from Muskegon from Pentwater. The barge came loose as the towline was being shortened to enter the harbor. A tugboat tied on behind the barge was cast loose, and the barge grounded and started taking on water.  The 3-man barge crew was rescued by Coast Guard using a small skiff as shallow water and heavy ice kept their larger motor lifeboat away. The barge eventually broke in two. In what the papers called "a Christmas Miracle", dozens of volunter contractors using bulldozers, cranes and trucks worked to salvage much of the equipment, avoiding a huge loss for the owners.
A small  wooden bulk freighter stranded on Little Point Sable in 1885 & 1887, but the 3rd visit to to the point left her to break up in shallows near Lee's Pier.
This small schooner was overwhelmed by weather in an 1886 November storm.  The wreck is sometimes buried by shifting sands.

This 320 foot whaleback stranded at the entrance to Muskegon Harbor on November 30, 1934 while trying to enter the harbor to escape a storm. Her wreckage is broken and twisted in about 15 feet of water next to the north break wall of the Muskegon Channel.
A construction barge originally built as a 3-mast schooner, she was swamped by waves and sits in shallow water, mostly buried in sand.

This very sturdy, twin engine vessel built in 1864 to haul iron ore from Lake Superior during the Civil War. She was braced by dual “hogging” arches on her sides.  Later she was converted to a freight and passenger vessel. On September 15, 1873 she was carrying a general freight cargo when she foundered off Grand Haven in about 120 feet of water. The wreck has begun to settle and collapse into the sand, but the engines are still visible.
Built 161 ft long, she was lengthened to 202 ft for greater cargo capacity.  She burned at her winter dock in Ferrysburg where she remains.

properties.Builder: Hunter Swan and Wigham Richardson Ltd.
properties.Description: This steel bulk freighter was built in 1928 in England. The "Armistice Day” storm of 1940 claimed her as well as the Minch. Her broken remains now lie in 12 to 15 feet of water off Pentwater.

Built in 1896 in England as the Turret Chief, the Salvor was a 253 foot wooden pseudo-whaleback steamer converted to a steel bulk-freight barge. She foundered when under tow when the hawser snapped. The hull and stone cargo rests in 25 to 30 feet of water. Sand covers the midsection of the hull.

The State of Michigan foundered  off Whitehall when a piston rod was thrown through the bottom of her hull on October 18, 1901. She was a 165 ft wooden passenger and package freight steamer.  Her boiler and outer hull are exposed for divers to inspect in 60 to 75 feet of water.

This vessel stranded in a snowstorm just above Manistee.  His signals for assistance were not noticed ashore, and by the next day a building sea forced the crew to abandon the vessel, and it broke up.

After holding behind Whitefish Point for weather, she ventured out onto the lake heading west, only to run into a raging gale that stopped her progress.  Unable to reach shelter at Grand Island, she turned back towards the east but began leaking, and eventually ran into shallow water west of Vermilion.  The Crisp Point lifesavers had been alerted, but were unable to locate her in the dark when she lost power and her lights went out.  The crew in the stern reached shore in their lifeboat, but the bow boat was lost, and only one person reached shore alive.  The ship was quickly broken up.
Under tow by the M.T. Greene, she stranded off Vermilion Point in poor visibility.  The crew was taken off by lifesavers, and a sudden gale came up that tore the schooner-barge to pieces.
Sometimes referred to as "City of Cleveland", she grounded near Two-Hearted River, but was reccovered and converted to a barge in 1866.

One of 3 schooner-barges in tow of the Steemer Prentice, the Eureka broke her towline and disappeared in a midnight gale.  The next day the Winslow spotted the top of her mainmast and a bit of her bow sticking out of the water. Her yawl boat was still tied, so the crew did not have time to escape.

This wooden steamer sank in 1858 in 100 to 115 feet of water off Crisp Point. Bound for the Soo, she blew a propeller seal, split her stern post, filled with water and foundered quickly. Her cabin was blown off by the pressure and floated about for a while with its lights still burning. The crew and four passengers, including Frank Perew, the ship's owner, made it to shore in her boats, camped out overnight and then sailed one of her boats to Whitefish Point, where the schooner St. Paul brought them to the Soo. Her machinery was recovered in 1978-79 and now resides at the Smithsonian Museum in Washington, D.C. It is reputedly the oldest marine engine existing that was built in North America.

Run down by the William H. Mack in a thick fog, the Mitchell heeled over enough that a boom caught on the Mack, holding the vessels together.  This allowed the crew time to lay a ladder across, and most reached safety this way.  Six others launched the lifeboat, only to be overturned by the suction of the sinking Mitchell, but all were eventually recovered.  Only three went down with the coal-laden vessel, which lies inverted on the bottom.

Along with the Saturn, Jupiter was part of the tow of the sidewheeler John A. Dix leaving Marquette loaded with iron ore.  A fierce gale swept the lake, and the towlines snapped one by one. Both tows apparently grounded, holed their bottoms, and then were pulled back out to deeper water.

In a heavy gale, the Drake lost the line to her sinking consort Michigan, and then collided with the Michigan while trying to take off her crew.  She sprung a leak and foundered off Vermilion Point. The Northern Wave and Crescent City rescued the crews of both vessels. The Drake was located in 1978 in 45 ft.

The Miztec was built at Marine City, Michigan in 1890. On May 15, 1921, the 194 foot, three-masted schooner was carrying a load of salt in tow of the steamer Zillah. A storm arose suddenly and her line parted and she disappeared from sight. Her crew of seven was lost. The Miztec is now spread across the bottom in 45 to 55 feet of water.

The 186 foot lumber hooker Myron was built in 1888. On November 22, 1919, she began to leak in a terrific northwest gale. Her crew cut a barge in tow loose and prepared to abandon ship, but the seas were too high. Despite the steamer Adriatic trying to block the weather and three attempts by the Lifesaving Service, the Myron sank with seventeen on board. The captain survived by standing on the pilothouse when it floated free. Located in 1972, the Myron lies broken into scattered debris in about 50 feet of water.

In 1887 the Niagara was coming from Wisconsin with a cargo of iron ore in tow of the steamer Australasia. During a severe September gale the tow line broke. The Niagara slipped into the wave-troughs and shifted her iron ore cargo, capsized and sank.  She was reportedly overloaded by about 250 tons. The nine member crew escaped the boat but were lost when her lifeboat capsized. The Niagara was located in 1972, the hull lying alongside a large pile of ore.

She was used as a fish tug as well as a small packet boat.  Reports conflict on this vessel, this wreckage was discovered in 1997, uncovered by shifting sands, but Pat Labadie and other sources report she was recovered and converted to a diesel, and used as a towboat called South Shore, lost November or December 1932 on Lake Michigan.

Striking on the outer bar after leaving the lumber dock at Deer Park, the captain thought he could work the ship over when the seas rose.  However, the building waves turned her broadside, where she started breaking up. Lifesavers rescued the entire crew, but later the captain remembered that his dog had been left in the cabin. The lifesavers made another perilous trip to rescue the dog as well, and the vessel eventually went to pieces.

The 237 foot wooden steamer Panther was built in 1890. On June 26, 1916, she was heading toward Sault Ste. Marie with a cargo of grain. As she was proceeding across a fog-covered Whitefish Bay, she was rammed by the steamer James J. Hill. The Hill kept running into the hole until the Panther�s crew clambered aboard. She sank quickly when the Hill backed away. The Panther was found in 1975 in 90 to 110 feet of water. Divers can see two anchors in the bow area, grain cargo, and tools in the stern.

Bound from Portage Entry to Buffalo with a load of stone, the Marsh began leaking badly during the night. The captain sent the crew up the masts and burned signal flares, alerting the Crisp Point Lifesavers. After a long hard row to the wreck, they came alongside just as the ship lurched and settled to the bottom. The woman cook was tossed into the wreckage, but the lifesavers charged in and rescued her, then began taking crewman from the masts to shore, a few at a time. Lifesavers stripped the wreck of everything useful over the next few days, but she was still a huge loss to her owners.
This work barge broke free from her mooring where she was working on the Whitefish Point breakwalls.  She lies nearly inverted, with her steam crane and other machinery holding her up off the bottom.

This whaleback sank at the entrance to the St. Mary's River when she was rammed by the Northern Queen. This is a relatively shallow dive, but it is in shipping traffic lanes so you must contact Sault Control before diving this site.

Along with the Jupiter, Saturn was part of the tow of the sidewheeler John A. Dix leaving Marquette loaded with iron ore.   A fierce gale swept the lake, and the towlines snapped one by one.  Both tows apparently grounded, holed their bottoms, and then were pulled back out to deeper water.

Only a day before the Pacific grounded, the Starucca stranded firmly about 10 miles east of Grand Marais. Two of her crew reached shore and alerted the Deer Park lifesavers, who rescued the remaining crew.  Portions of her cargo of general merchandise were salvaged before she went to pieces.

The wooden steamer Vienna, built in 1873, measured 191 feet in length. She sank on September 17, 1892 following a collision with the propeller Nipigon about four miles below Whitefish Point. The Vienna was carrying a cargo of iron ore with the schooner Mattie C. Bell in tow. Following the collision, the Nipigon towed the Vienna for about an hour, but the vessel went down in deep water. No lives were lost. Her stern rises majestically from a depth of 145 feet, the bow portion has collapsed. Divers can find a mix of tools and artifacts scattered around the wreck.

While at anchor, the crew was taking advantage of the weather to do laundry using a small stove in the forecastle. Leaving it unattended while they atto dinner, a fire broke out, and it gained ground quickly when it reached the tarred decks.  The crew escaped into the yawl boat.
This small steamer was towing her barges Grey Oak and Ryan off Emerson in Whitefish Bay when she burst into flames.  The barges were cast free and the Yosemite drifted ashore and settled.
